questions.question_text: What are you allowed to use the left-hand hard shoulder for?

options.a: Only for emergency vehicles when a traffic jam has formed.
options.b: For overtaking slower vehicles on the left to maintain Highway flow.
options.c: For stopping and parking, and for driving with slow vehicles.

questions.explanation: According to the manual, the left-hand hard shoulder is designated specifically for stopping and parking or for use by slow-moving vehicles. Overtaking on any hard shoulder is strictly prohibited.

questions.question_text: You are driving in dense fog on a road outside a built-up area. Are you allowed to drive in the middle of the road continuously straddling the broken white line?

options.a: No, because it could represent a danger to oncoming traffic.
options.b: Yes, it is recommended to ensure you stay centered on the roadway.
options.c: Only if visibility is less than 10 metres and you use hazards.

questions.explanation: Straddling the center line is dangerous as it puts you in the path of oncoming traffic. The manual requires you to stay in your lane and use the left-hand edge markings for orientation.

questions.question_text: What must you reckon with on this Highway car park?

options.a: That you have absolute right-of-way over all entering vehicles.
options.b: People suddenly stepping onto the roadway.
options.c: Vehicles will only be entering from the right-hand side.

questions.explanation: In Highway rest areas (car parks), you must anticipate pedestrians (motorists who have parked) stepping into the roadway unexpectedly and the danger of skidding when braking.

questions.question_text: Your vehicle has broken down on the Highway. What must you remember when having it towed away?

options.a: Both vehicles must have their hazard warning lights switched on and you must leave at the next exit.
options.b: Towing is only permitted for a maximum distance of 50 kilometres.
options.c: Only the vehicle being towed is required to use hazard lights.

questions.explanation: Safety regulations on the Highway require both vehicles to use hazard lights during towing and to exit the Highway at the very first opportunity.

questions.question_text: Where must you particularly reckon with dirt on the roadway and therefore danger of skidding?

options.a: On the approach to well-lit Highway bridges.
options.b: At junctions with farm tracks and near construction sites.
options.c: In built-up areas with a speed limit of 60 km/h.

questions.explanation: Dirt and mud are frequently pulled onto the main road at farm and construction exits, creating a slippery surface that causes skidding.

questions.question_text: What is the minimum distance that should normally be maintained from the vehicle in front outside built-up areas?

options.b: A distance in metres equal to the speed in km/h.
options.c: A fixed distance of 25 metres regardless of speed.

questions.explanation: The 'rule of thumb' for a safe gap outside built-up areas is to maintain a distance in metres that is at least half of your current speed value.

questions.question_text: Where must you be prepared to encounter sudden fog?

options.a: On steep uphill gradients during mid-day heat.
options.b: In urban built-up areas with high-rise buildings.
options.c: Near rivers, lakes, and in marshy areas.

questions.explanation: Sudden fog is most likely to occur near bodies of water or low-lying marshy ground where moisture levels are high.

questions.question_text: For which purposes is a horn allowed to be used outside built-up areas?

options.a: To signal your arrival to friends at a residence.
options.b: As a warning signal or an overtaking signal.
options.c: To signal frustration at slow-moving farm vehicles.

questions.explanation: Outside built-up areas, the horn is legally permitted to warn of danger or to signal your intention to begin an overtaking maneuver.

questions.question_text: Where must you be particularly prepared for dangerous side winds on the Highway?

options.a: On bridges and behind cuts in the landscape.
options.b: Only when overtaking vehicles with a total mass under 3.5 t.
options.c: When driving in dense forest areas with no clearings.

questions.explanation: Exposed structures like bridges and the sudden open space following a cutting in the landscape are the most common areas for dangerous crosswinds.

questions.question_text: What can result in aquaplaning (sliding on wet roads)?

options.a: Driving with dipped headlights on a wet surface.
options.b: High speed, worn tyres, and grooves in the roadway.
options.c: New tyres with a profile depth of over 3mm.

questions.explanation: Aquaplaning occurs when speed is too high for the tyres to displace water, especially if the tyres are worn or if the road has grooves that collect water.

questions.question_text: When is there a danger of underestimating your own speed?

options.a: When you have just entered a Highway from a narrow country road.
options.b: When driving in a traffic jam with frequent gear changes.
options.c: When the road is wide and there are no trees or buildings at the edge.

questions.explanation: A lack of stationary visual reference points (trees/fences) makes it difficult for the brain to perceive speed accurately, often leading to underestimation.

questions.question_text: What does a front-wheel drive car tend to do if you accelerate too much on a bend?

options.a: The front end tends to turn out to the side.
options.b: The rear end tends to turn out to the side.
options.c: The vehicle steering will lock in the center position.

questions.explanation: Excessive acceleration in a front-wheel drive car causes the front wheels to lose grip, making the front of the car push toward the outside of the curve.

questions.question_text: You have a reaction time of 1 second. What is the total STOPPING distance you must reckon with by rule of thumb at 50 km/h?
questions.explanation: Total Stopping Distance = Reaction Distance (15m) + Braking Distance (25m). The rule of thumb result is 40 metres.

questions.question_text: What is the reaction distance by rule of thumb if you are travelling at 60 km/h?
questions.explanation: The formula for reaction distance is (Speed/10 x 3). At 60 km/h, this is 6 x 3 = 18 metres.

questions.question_text: To which motor vehicles is the recommended Highway speed of 130 km/h intended?

options.a: For trucks with a permissible total mass of over 3.5 t.
options.c: For buses and vehicles towing caravans.

questions.explanation: The 130 km/h recommended speed is intended specifically for cars and motorcycles under favorable conditions.
